{{Infobox book| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = 100 Things Successful People Do | image = 100 Things Successful People Do - UK Paperback and Hardback editions side by side.jpg | caption = | author = [[Nigel Cumberland]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom & United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[self help]], [[leadership]], [[self-development]] | publisher = [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray Learning]], [[Hodder & Stoughton]], Nicolas Brealey, [[Hachette UK]] | release_date = August 11, 2016 (hardcover), May 4, 2017 (paperback), | media_type = [[Hardcover]], [[Paperback]], [[Audiobook]] and [[E-book]] | pages = 224 (Hardcover 1st edition) | isbn = 978-185-7-88662-7 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living''''' is a self-help guide by [[Nigel Cumberland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/6978123.Nigel_Cumberland |title=Nigel Cumberland (Author of 100 Things Successful People Do) |publisher=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Nigel-Cumberland/e/B0034P71X2/ref=dp_byline_cont_book_1 |title=Nigel Cumberland: Books, Biogs, Audiobooks, Discussions |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>https://www.hodder.co.uk/search.page?SearchText=nigel+cumberland</ref>
==Publication== The book was published in August 2016 by [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray Learning]] in the UK, a part of [[Hodder & Stoughton]] (imprint of [[Hachette UK]]).<ref>{{cite web|author=Time remaining -- days -- hours -- minutes -- seconds |url=https://www.hodder.co.uk/books/detail.page?isbn=9781473635067 |title=Nigel Cumberland - 100 Things Successful People Do - Hodder & Stoughton |publisher=Hodder.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> The US edition<ref>{{cite web|author=Barnes & Noble |url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/100-things-successful-people-do-nigel-cumberland/1124655804?ean=9781857886627 |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living by Nigel Cumberland, Hardcover | Barnes & Noble® |publisher=Barnesandnoble.com |date=2016-10-25 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> came out in October 2016 published by another Hachette UK imprint, Nicolas Brealey Publishing. The paperback version<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/100-Things-Successful-People-Exercises/dp/1473635055/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr= |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living: Amazon.co.uk: Nigel Cumberland: 9781473635050: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> was published in the UK in May 2017 with a US edition coming out in late 2017. The book has a foreword written by [[Marshall Goldsmith]]. It has featured in various suggested reading lists in the mainstream media.<ref>http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/health/723684/Self-help-book-selection-Autumn-2016</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jenna Farmer |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/indybest/books/non-fiction-books/best-books-for-entrepreneurs-2018-beginners-all-time-a8277266.html |title=9 best books for entrepreneurs |publisher=The Independent |date=2018-03-28 |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref>
Translated editions of the book include in [[Dutch language|Dutch]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Nigel Cumberland (Author) |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/9047010795/ref=sr_1_12?ie=UTF8&qid=1489115930&sr=8-12&keywords=Nigel+Cumberland |title=100 dingen die succesvolle mensen doen: Slim werken en prettig leven: Amazon.co.uk: Nigel Cumberland: 9789047010791: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> [[Romanian language|Romanian]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.librariaverona.ro/produse/100-de-pasi-pentru-o-viata-de-succes-autor-nigel-cumberland-editura-niculescu/7430 |title=100 DE PASI PENTRU O VIATA DE SUCCES AUTOR NIGEL CUMBERLAND EDITURA NICULESCU - Dezvoltare personala - Libraria Verona - Librarie Online - Carti la preturi mici |publisher=Librariaverona.ro |date= |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref> [[Russian language|Russian]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mann-ivanov-ferber.ru/books/ne-zhalej-ni-o-chem/ |title=Не жалей ни о чем (Найджел Камберленд) — купить в МИФе |publisher=Mann-ivanov-ferber.ru |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> and [[Slovak language|Slovak]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.databazeknih.cz/knihy/100-veci-ktore-robia-uspesni-ludia-343943 |title=100 vecí, ktoré robia úspešní ľudia - Nigel Cumberland | Databáze knih |publisher=Databazeknih.cz |date= |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref> Upcoming translations include into [[Arabic]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]]<ref>http://anthearights.com/html/upload/files/doc_pages/78/bg/lbf17%20hodder%20+%20jm%20non%20fic1/lbf17%20hodder%20+%20jm%20non%20fic1.pdf</ref> and [[Bengali language|Bangla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.priyo.com/search?key=%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%B2%20%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0%20%E0%A7%A7%E0%A7%A6%E0%A7%A6%20%E0%A6%9C%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%BE|title=সফল ব্যক্তিদের ১০০ জীবনচর্চা|last=Tuba, translator of [[Bengali language|Bangla]] version|first=Bushra Amin|date=|website=প্রিয়.কম|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171120050709/https://www.priyo.com/search?key=%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%B2%20%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0%20%E0%A7%A7%E0%A7%A6%E0%A7%A6%20%E0%A6%9C%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%BE|archive-date=2017-11-20|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-10-02|df=}}</ref>
The book is available to be used in schools for the [[visually impaired]] in the United States through the [[Bookshare|bookshare service]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Bookshare: Homepage |url=https://www.bookshare.org/browse/book/1395852?returnPath=L2Jyb3dzZS9sYXRlc3Q/bW9kdWxlTmFtZT1wdWJsaWMmc29ydE9yZGVyPVRJVExFJmFkZGVkPU1PTlRIJmxpbWl0PTEwMCZvZmZzZXQ9MA%3D%3D |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Habits, Mindsets and Activities For Creating Your Own Success Story |publisher=Bookshare |date=2016-10-25 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref>
==Contents== The book's 100 chapters each cover in a couple of pages one of the 100 things that the author suggests successful people do. A reviewer writes: "the book, subtitled Little Exercises For Successful Living, is easily digestible (perhaps even as a tip a day), with each spread over two pages – the first explaining the concept and the second featuring practical exercises and activities to apply it to your life."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/the-life/book-review-unlearn-it-all-to-move-ahead |title=Book review: Unlearn it all to move ahead | The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date=2016-09-06 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> Another adds: "each secret to success is a powerful reminder of the ways you can make your life – and other's – more satisfied, at work, at home and in your relationships, with your health, wealth and in retirement."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/successful-leaders-little-secrets-659239.html |title=Successful leaders' little secrets - Business - Arabian- Business -.com |publisher=Arabianbusiness.com |date=2017-01-17 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox person | image = Artist 2wenty.jpeg | caption = Self Portrait, by 2wenty in 2013 | name = 2wenty | birth_name = George Barshid Mccollon | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]] | birth_date = | occupation = Artist, photographer | years_active = 2011–present | website = }}
'''2wenty''' is an American [[Mixed media|mixed-media]] artist and [[photographer]] from [[Los Angeles]]. He is known for using light as the central theme in his work. 2wenty comes from a background in lighting television and film which gives him an intimate understanding of how light works. The sources of light he utilizes for his light paintings are handmade, as well as creating the LED paintings by hand. His works can be viewed both nationally and internationally in Los Angeles, [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], and [[London, England|London]].
== Art career == [[File:Facebook Cigarettes poster by 2wenty.png|thumb|right|Facebook Social Cigarettes poster by 2wenty, 2011]] 2wenty first emerged in 2011, when his ''Facebook Social Cigarettes'' posters started appearing in technology blogs all over the internet and on the streets of Los Angeles and San Francisco.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.streetartsf.com/interview/artist-interview-2wenty/|title=2Wenty Street Art SF|work=Street Art SF|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> The posters featured a pack of cigarettes with the [[Facebook]] logo and a tag that read, "Social Cigarettes."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laist.com/2011/04/06/social_cigarettes_street_artist_adm.php|title='Social Cigarettes' Street Artist Admits Facebook Addiction|work=LAist|accessdate=29 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140803150238/http://laist.com/2011/04/06/social_cigarettes_street_artist_adm.php|archivedate=3 August 2014|df=}}</ref> He created over one hundred of the posters, comparing [[Facebook]] consumption with that of "cancer sticks."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/fishbowlla/facebook-street-art-2wenty-forbes-kashmir-hill_b26020|title=FishbowlLA|work=mediabistro.com|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> 2wenty also created three-dimensional versions of the posters, complete with a surgeon general warning, "[[Facebook]] may cause loss of time, poor work ethic, obesity, social disorder and possible interference of destiny. Use at your own risk."
2wenty has had multiple collaborations with fellow aritst, [[Gregory Siff]], in addition to This Means Mar. In December 2013, 2wenty was invited by Mar to show and create one of his "signature" light paintings at his solo show 'I Crave Love', which was held at Lab Art Gallery in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.shophex.com/blog/events/hex-x-i-crave-love-a-solo-show-by-this-means-mar-at-lab-art/ |title=I Crave Love: A Solo Show At Lab Art LA, Shop Hex Blog, December 2013 |access-date=2015-09-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304130424/http://www.shophex.com/blog/events/hex-x-i-crave-love-a-solo-show-by-this-means-mar-at-lab-art/ |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.labartgallery.com/blog/2011/12/21/this-means-mar/ This Means Mar]</ref>
His works have been exhibited in Los Angeles,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesiteunscene.com/infobox/2wenty-street-art-gallery-2/|title=2wenty: Street Art Gallery|work=The Site Unscene|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> San Francisco, Washington D.C. and at Miami's Art Basel.<ref>[http://miami.happeningmag.com/basel-house-epicenter-street-art/ Art Basel House: Epicenter For Street Art, Happening Mag, December 2014]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://according2g.com/2011/05/20-questions-with-2wenty/|title=20 Questions with 2wenty|work=according2g.com|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> He has been featured in [[Forbes]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/elee45ilem/facebook-cigarettes-2/|title=Facebook "cigarettes" - In Photos: Facebook Street Art|author=TJ McCue|work=Forbes|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kashmirhill/2011/04/06/l-a-street-artists-unfiltered-take-on-facebook-social-cigarettes/|title=L.A. Street Artist's Unfiltered Take on Facebook: 'Social Cigarettes'|author=Kashmir Hill|date=6 April 2011|work=Forbes|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> [[Lifestyle magazine|Beverly Hills Lifestyle Magazine]], LA Canvas, Leveled Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leveledmag.com/2012/09/light-drawing-photography-by-2wenty/|title=Light Drawing Photography by 2wenty|work=Leveled Magazine|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> Melrose and Fairfax,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://melroseandfairfax.blogspot.com/2011/02/hooked-up-free-street-art-from-2wenty.html|title=MELROSEandFAIRFAX: Hooked Up - Free Street Art from 2wenty|work=melroseandfairfax.blogspot.com|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref> Gawker and as background themes for the, "My Yahoo", main page on [[Yahoo.com]].
== Photography == [[File:Lightman, photograph by 2wenty, 2013.jpg|thumb|right|"Lightman", Los Angeles, 2013, Photograph by 2wenty]] 2wenty expands his oeuvre into [[Light painting|light painting photography]]. Through long exposures, the camera captures not only the subject, but also the source of light the artist moves across his "canvas". Within these detailed images," There is a depth and other worldliness that records both place and passage of time", says 2wenty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oaklandartmurmur.org/events/between-paint-and-light-2wenty-and-gregory-siff-at-loakal-2013-06-01/|title=Between Paint and Light: 2wenty and Gregory Siff at Loakal|work=oaklandartmurmur.org|accessdate=29 March 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.leveledmag.com/2012/09/light-drawing-photography-by-2wenty/ Light Drawing Photography by 2wenty]</ref> [[File:"Untitled", Photograph by 2wenty, Malibu 2012.jpg|thumb|right|"Untitled", Malibu 2012, Photograph by 2wenty]]

{{BLP sources|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist |image = |name = Aalias |background = non_performing_personnel |birth_name = Aaron Kleinstub | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|8|20}} |origin = [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], United States |genre = [[Rap]], [[Rhythm & Blues|R&B]], [[Pop music|pop]] |years_active = 2013–present |associated_acts = [[Eminem]], [[Rihanna]], Frequency, [[Bebe Rexha]], [[Melanie Martinez (singer)|Melanie Martinez]] |website = [http://imprint180.com/artists/aalias/ Imprint One80] }} '''Aaron Kleinstub''' (born August 20, 1989), better known by his stage name '''Aalias''', is an [[United States|American]] music producer and musician from [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. ==Biography== Aaron “Aalias” Kleinstub is a songwriter, composer, producer and multi-instrumentalist.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cleveland.com/popmusic/index.ssf/2013/10/aalias_--_aka_geauga_countys_a.html |title=Aalias - a.k.a. Geauga County's Aaron Kleinstub - steps into big time as co-producer of Eminem's 'The Monster' |publisher=cleveland.com |date=2013-10-31 |accessdate=2015-09-06}} As a teenager, he won numerous awards playing jazz trumpet, including the Yamaha Young Performing Artist Award, honorable mention from the National Association for the Advancement of the Arts, a Berklee Music Camp scholarship and a selection to perform in the Grammy Jazz Band at 16.{{cite web|url=http://www.primarywave.com/artist/MTc2ODMtZjgzZDgw/ |title=Primary Wave Music - Aalias |publisher=Primarywave.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-06}} After graduating from Kenston High School in Chagrin Falls, Ohio, Aalias moved to New York to study at Juilliard. He later transferred to Berklee College of Music, where he graduated with a focus in music production. Aalias is perhaps best known for co-writing and co-producing the #1 hit song [[The Monster (song)|"The Monster"]] by [[Eminem]] featuring [[Rihanna]]. "The Monster" reached #1 on eight separate Billboard charts, including four weeks at #1 on the Hot 100{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5862620/pitbull-kesha-take-timber-to-top-of-hot-100 |title=Pitbull, Ke$ha Take 'Timber' to Top of Hot 100 |publisher=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2014-08-10}} and thirteen weeks at #1 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/5900956/beyonce-earns-7th-no-1-on-hot-rbhip-hop-songs-no-1-with-drunk-in |title=Beyonce Earns 7th No. 1 on Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs No. 1 with 'Drunk In Love' |publisher=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2014-08-10}} It also topped the charts in twelve countries including Australia, Canada, France, Ireland, New Zealand, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom and won a Grammy for Best/Rap Sung Collaboration.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/features/leisure/entertainment/kleinstub-rocks-with-grammy-award-winning-the-monster/article_dcf8a856-b864-11e4-9e2b-831071b136d3.html |title=Kleinstub rocks with Grammy Award-winning ‘The Monster’ - Cleveland Jewish News: Entertainment |publisher=Cleveland Jewish News |date=2015-02-19 |accessdate=2015-09-06}} ==Selected discography== {{expand list|date=July 2015}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Artist ! Song ! Album (label year) |- |[[The Kite String Tangle]] |"Give it Time" feat. Aalias |(Warner Music Australia 2018) |- |[[Jaira Burns]] |"Low Key in Love" |(Interscope 2018) |- |[[Eminem]] |"Revival (Interlude)" feat. Alice and the Glass Lake
[Produced with [[Frequency (record producer)|Frequency]] for Whole Doubts] |[[Revival (Eminem album)|Revival]] (Interscope 2017) |- |Whole Doubts |”Leave” feat. Kevin Garrett |(Whole Doubts 2017) |- |[[Robin Schulz]] & Aalias |"Fools" feat. IRO |Uncovered (Warner 2017) |- |John Splithoff |"Show Me" feat. {{Infobox tennis biography |name = Adam Baworowski |fullname = |image = Adam baworowski.jpg |caption = Baworowski (center), during a reception for the 1939 Davis Cup match between Poland and China |country = {{flagicon|Austria}} Austria (1918–38)
{{flagicon|Poland}} Poland (1938–41)
{{flagicon|Nazi Germany}} Germany (1941–43) |residence = |birth_date = 9 August 1913 |birth_place = [[Vienna]], Austria-Hungary |death_date ={{death year and age|1943|1913}} |death_place = [[Stalingrad]], USSR |height = |turnedpro = 1929 (amateur tour) |retired = 1941 |plays = Right-handed (one-handed backhand) |careerprizemoney = |singlesrecord = |singlestitles = |highestsinglesranking = |AustralianOpenresult = |FrenchOpenresult = 4R ([[1937 French Championships - Men's Singles|1937]], [[1938 French Championships - Men's Singles|1938]]) |Wimbledonresult = 1R ([[1933 Wimbledon Championships - Men's Singles|1933]], [[1936 Wimbledon Championships - Men's Singles|1936]], [[1939 Wimbledon Championships - Men's Singles|1939]]) |USOpenresult = |Othertournaments = |WHCCresult = |WCCCresult = |Olympicsresult = |doublesrecord = |doublestitles = |highestdoublesranking = |AustralianOpenDoublesresult = |FrenchOpenDoublesresult = SF (1939) |WimbledonDoublesresult = 2R (1936, 1939) |USOpenDoublesresult = |Mixed = yes | FrenchOpenMixedresult = 2R (1937) | WimbledonMixedresult = 2R (1936, 1939) | Team = yes | DavisCupresult = SFEu ([[1936 International Lawn Tennis Challenge|1936]]) }} '''Adam Baworowski''' ({{IPA-pol|ˈadam bavɔˈrɔfskʲi}}; born 9 August 1913 in Vienna – 1943 in Stalingrad) was an [[Austria]]n-[[Poland|Polish]] [[tennis]] player. == Biography == ===Early life and family=== Count Adam Baworowski descended from the [[szlachta|Polish noble]] family ''Baworowski''. He was the son of Count Rudolf Baworowski and Austrian Countess Maria Chorynsky the former who was the [[Chamberlain (office)|Chamberlain]] of [[Franz Joseph I of Austria]] and had estates in [[Lviv]] and where Adam often spent his childhood years.{{sfn|Le Gaulois 1901; Mariages}}{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} He had three brothers and three sisters, Emil, Stefan, Rudolf, Matylda, Marya and Franciszka. He went to school in [[Vienna]] and as the family spoke German at home Adam was alienated from his Polish roots in the beginning.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} He started playing tennis at a very early age and started taking coaching lessons from the Van Dycków brothers. He attended the tennis club at the [[Prater]] where he had a chance to meet [[Georg von Metaxa]], his later Davis Cup teammate and friend.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} In 1927 he had a victory over [[Henner Henkel]] at the Youth Games. In 1929 at the age of 13 he already defeated then-Polish champion [[Maximilian Stolarow]].{{sfn|Rzeczpospolita 2003; Last summer on the Riviera}} In 1931, he won the Austrian junior tennis championships as well as the international junior championships of Berlin in singles and doubles.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} He was ranked tenth on the Austrian rankings.{{sfn|Straits Times 1935; Lawn Tennis team visiting India}} The next year he was classified fifth.{{sfn|Le Figaro 1932; Tennis}} While in 1934 he climbed to number four on the same list.{{sfn|Straits Times 1935; Lawn Tennis team visiting India}} In 1935 he won the national singles and doubles championships and drew attention with back to back straight victories against famed players [[Franz Wilhelm Matejka]] and [[Hermann Artens]] to be crowned champion.{{sfn|Straits Times 1935; Lawn Tennis team visiting India}}{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} Subsequently, he rose to the second place after Matejka.{{sfn|The Sydney Morning Herald 1935; Italian Ranking list}} Later he became member of the [[Wiener Park Club]].{{sfn|Huszadik Század 1935; Emil Gabrowitz won the UTE tennis tournament}} ===International tennis career=== He was first drafted into the Austrian Davis Cup troupe in 1933 only for the doubles rubber teaming with [[Herbert Kinzl]] with whom he reached the doubles finals of the [[Sheffield]] tournament later that year.{{sfn|The Canberra Times 1933; Sheffield tennis tournament}} He played again in the Cup in 1936 along with [[Georg von Metaxa]] and reached the semifinals of the European zone.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} He won the [[Austrian Open Kitzbühel|Austrian Championships]] in the same year. He twice won the International Polish Championship of Warsaw in the doubles partnering [[Pat Hughes (tennis)|Pat Hughes]] in 1933 and [[Hans Redl]] in 1937. {{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} He was twice finalist in [[Budapest]] in 1935 and 1937.{{sfn|Huszadik Század 1935; Emil Gabrowitz won the UTE tennis tournament}}{{sfn|Huszadik Század 1937; 1937 Hungarian tennis championships}} In 1937 he still held the second spot on the Austrian rankings next to von Metaxa.{{sfn|Ilustrowana Republika 1937; The best tennis players of Austria and England}} In 1936 he won the [[Capri]] tournament meeting [[Jacques Jamain]] in the championship match. He also won the mixed doubles with [[Toto Zehden]].{{sfn|Le Figaro 1936; Bavarowsky}} In January 1937 he lost the doubles final in [[Saint Moritz]], playing with von Metaxa, to Frenchmen [[Christian Boussus]] and [[Paul Féret]].{{sfn|Le Figaro 1937; French victories at the Saint-Moritz tournament}} In March he lost the Nice title to [[Kho Sin-Kie]] in straight sets. At the same tournament he reached the double final as well with von Metaxa.{{sfn|Le Figaro 1937; Kho-Sin-Kie victor at Nice}} In April he clinched the Monegasque Championships by beating [[Marcel Bernard]] in a five set match. He also took the doubles title with von Metaxa defeating [[Daniel Prenn]] and [[Vladimir Landau]].{{sfn|Le Figaro 1937; Marcel Bernard is beaten by Bawarowski in Monte Carlo}} In March 1938 he was victorious at the Cannes L.T.C. tournament where he eliminated Swedish champion [[Karl Schroeder (tennis)|Karl Schroeder]]. Schroeder took revenge in the doubles final where he teamed up with seasoned player [[Jacques Brugnon]] of the [[The Four Musketeers (tennis)|Four Musketeers]] to stop the Baworowski-von Metaxa duo in a five set match.{{sfn|Le Figaro 1938; Cannes L.T.C. finals}} At the [[French Open|French Championships]], Baworowski reached the fourth round in 1937 and 1938. At Wimbledon, he lost his initial match on three occasions (1933, 1936, 1939). After the "[[Anschluss]]", the annexation of Austria into Nazi Germany, in March 1938, Baworowski decided to join the Polish Davis Cup team as he didn't want to lose his family's estates in Poland.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} Upon arrival in Poland he gave a few interviews, condemning the "Anschluss" and the policy of the Nazi authorities. His statements were widely covered in the Western media. He joined the [[Legia Warsaw]] and on 3 May 1938 he participated in a friendly match between Poland and Germany, and a few days later played in a match in a Legia Warsaw-Stockholm meeting. He quickly moved up to second place on the list of [[Polish Tennis Association]] right behind [[Ignacy Tłoczyński]]. He was victorious again in the doubles at the [[Katowice]] tournament partnering Tłoczyński and the duo represented Poland in the Central European Cup and claimed the trophy after beating [[Yugoslavia Davis Cup team|Yugoslavia]] and [[Czechoslovakia Davis Cup team|Czechoslovakia]].{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} The last peaceful season in 1939 kicked off well for him. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs sponsored Baworowski [[French Riviera]] tour and it paid off well. At [[Cannes]] he was only beaten in the final by [[Yvon Petra]]. In [[Juan-les-Pins]] he proved to be unstoppable and defeated [[Robert Abdesselam]] for the title and carried on this streak at [[Nice]] through the final against [[Antoine Gentien]]. After this great season opener he suffered injury, which affected his Davis Cup tie against [[Germany Davis Cup team|Germany]] and in the [[1939 French Championships (tennis)|French Championships]]. However he was a doubles semifinalist along with [[Ignacy Tłoczyński]] at Roland Garros. Despite his bad shape he still secured the Polish National Doubles championship alongside Tłoczyński.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} === World War II and death === At the outbreak of [[World War II]], after returning from [[Monaco]] with a silver medal of the [[1939 International University Games]] Baworowski was residing in Paris where his family lived. When he heard about the outbreak of the war he was determined to join the [[Polish army]] although his parents begged him to stay. When he arrived to the East Railway Station of Warsaw, The German [[Luftwaffe]] was already bombarding the area. The passengers fled from the trains to nearby trenches. Apparently he was successfully enlisted.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} The next time he met his cousin Eugene Paul Baworowski in the streets of Warsaw in the first days of [[Occupation of Poland (1939–45)|occupation]] he was about to get in touch with the [[Polish resistance movement in World War II|Polish Resistance]]. As the 6 September 1939 decree issued by the Wehrmacht command pursued every Polish citizen who reached the military age to be sent to a [[POW]] camp the [[Gestapo]] soon arrested and sent him to a camp. Only his ties to the Chorynsky noble family and to the former [[Austrian Tennis Federation]] saved him from further reprisals.{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} In 1941, he took part in the German war championships at [[Braunschweig]] and reached the final which he lost to [[Kurt Gies]] in five sets.{{Gillmeister, pp. 60 and 72-74, notes 60-62}} He was practising in the [[Rot-Weiss Tennis Club]] of [[Berlin]]. He further represented Germany in the Danube Cup, which was a wartime substitute for the Central European Cup. Baworowski later joined the German [[Wehrmacht]] and was killed in action in the beginning of 1943 during the [[Battle of Stalingrad]].{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} He served as a [[Hauptmann]]. On December 21, 1942, when the Luftwaffe evacuated his troops he ceded his place on the last flight to a heavily injured soldier and decided to stay in the trenches with his subordinates. He was hit by the Soviets and died in agony without receiving any medical help. {{sfn|Konecki|2003}} ==Playing style== According to Kordian Tarasiewicz contemporary senior Polish tennis Player Baworowski was "[...] was a well established tennis player on the European courts and represented a versatile offensive [style], especially had a well mastered game at the net".{{sfn|sportowahistoria.pl website}} ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Adam Baworowski''' |2= 2. Rudolf Baworów-Baworowski |3= 3. Franziska (Fanny) Anna Gräfin von Chorinsky Freiin von Ledske |4= 4. Josef Maria Matthäus Graf Baworowski |5= 5. Franziska Dominika Maximiliane Gräfin zu Hardegg auf Glatz und im Machlande |6= 6. Victor Paul Graf von Chorinsky Freiherr von Ledske |7= 7. revision.text:
{{Infobox serial killer | name=Amy Archer-Gilligan | image=Amy-Archer-Gilligan.png | caption= | birthname= | alias=Sister | birth_date=October 1873 | birth_place=[[Milton Center Historic District|Milton]], [[Connecticut]] | death_date={{death date and age|1962|04|23|1873|10|1}} | death_place=[[Middletown, Connecticut|Middletown]], Connecticut | victims=10–50 | country=United States | states=Connecticut | beginyear=1910 | endyear=1917 | apprehended={{start date and age|1917}} | penalty=[[Death penalty|Death]], later sent to [[insane asylum]] | motive =[[Life insurance]] money }}
'''Amy Duggan''' "'''Sister'''" '''Archer-Gilligan''' (October 1873<ref name= aaol>{{cite news| url= http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/01/17/2010-01-17_comedy_and_killing_truth_to_arsenic__old_lace.html |first= Mara| last= Bovsun| title= True crime story behind classic comedy, 'Arsenic & Old Lace'| website= NYDailyNews.com}}</ref> – April 23, 1962)<ref name= courant>{{cite news| work= [[The Hartford Courant]]| title= Archer-Gilligan obituary| access-date= }}</ref> was a [[Windsor, Connecticut]], [[nursing home]] proprietor and serial killer. She murdered at least five people by poisoning them. One of her victims was her second husband, Michael Gilligan; the others were residents of her nursing home.
It is possible that she was involved in more deaths. The authorities counted 48 deaths in her nursing home, the "Archer Home for the Elderly and Infirm."
The case attracted wide publicity at the time and has been cited as an inspiration for the play ''[[Arsenic and Old Lace (play)|Arsenic and Old Lace]]'' and for [[Frank Capra]]'s later [[Arsenic and Old Lace (film)|film of the same name]].
==Childhood and marriages== Amy E. Duggan was born in October 1868 to James Duggan and Mary Kennedy in [[Milton Center Historic District|Milton, Connecticut]], the eighth of ten children.<ref name= conndeaths>{{cite |work= Connecticut Death Records| title= Mary Kennedy Duggan, 1838-1915}}</ref><ref name= censusrecs>''1870 US Census of Litchfield, Connecticut, p. 73''; ''1880 US Census of Litchfield, Connecticut''; ''1900 US Census of Litchfield, Connecticut'', sheet 18B''; ''1900 US Census of Litchfield, Connecticut'', sheet 24A''; ''1910 US Census of Windsor, Connecticut'', p. 18.</ref> She attended the Milton School and the New Britain Normal School in 1890.<ref name= milton>{{cite book| title= Chronicles of Milton: Village Left Behind by Time |publisher= Milton Women's Club| location= Milton, Connecticut}}</ref>
Amy Duggan married James Archer in 1897. A daughter, Mary J. Archer, was born in December 1897.<ref name= censusrecs /> The Archers first became caretakers in 1901, hired to care for John Seymour, an elderly widower. They moved into his home in [[Newington, Connecticut]]. Seymour died in 1904. His heirs converted the residence into a [[boarding house]] for the elderly, and the Archers remained to provide care for the elderly for a fee. They paid rent to Seymour's family.<ref name= aaol/> They ran the boarding house as Sister Amy's Nursing Home for the Elderly.
In 1907, Seymour's heirs decided to sell the house. The Archers moved to [[Windsor, Connecticut]], and used their savings to purchase their own residence on Prospect Street in Windsor Center. They soon converted it into a business, Archer Home for the Elderly and Infirm.
James Archer died in 1910,<ref name= aaol /> apparently of natural causes. The official cause of his death was [[Bright's disease]], a generic term for [[Nephrology|kidney diseases]].<ref name= aaol /> Amy Archer had taken out an insurance policy on him a few weeks before his death. The policy benefit enabled her to continue operating Archer Home.
In 1913, Amy married Michael W. Gilligan, a widower with four adult sons.<ref name= census2>''1900 US Census of Windsor, Connecticut'', sheet 8A; ''1910 US Census of Windsor, Connecticut'', p. 12.</ref> He was reportedly wealthy and interested in both Amy and in investing in the Archer Home. However, on February 20, 1914,<ref name= mwgsdeath>{{cite web| url= https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.2/MDV2-1MM/p1| title= Connecticut Deaths and Burials record|deadurl= yes| website= familysearch.org}}{{dead link|date= December 2016}}</ref> after only three months married to Amy, Michael died.<ref name= aaol /> The official cause of death was "acute bilious attack" (in other words, [[Indigestion|severe indigestion]]).<ref name= aaol /> Amy was once again financially secure because during their short marriage her new husband had drawn up a [[will (law)|will]] which left his entire estate to her. The will would later be determined a [[forgery]] as it was apparently written in handwriting matching Amy Archer-Gilligan.<ref name= aaol />
==Murders== Between 1907 and 1917, there were 60 deaths in the Archer Home. Relatives of her clients grew suspicious as they tallied the large number of deaths. Only 12 residents died between 1907 and 1910, but 48 residents died between 1911 and 1916. Among them was Franklin R. Andrews, an apparently healthy man. On the morning of May 29, 1914, Andrews was doing some gardening in the Archer house. His robust physical condition deteriorated in a single day and he was dead by evening. The official cause of death was [[Peptic ulcer|gastric ulcer]].
After Andrews' siblings (including Nellie Pierce) came into possession of some of his letters, they noted occasions where Amy Archer-Gilligan was pressing their brother for money.<ref name= aaol /> Amy's clients showed a pattern of dying not long after giving her a large sum of money.
As the deaths continued, Nellie Pierce reported her suspicions to the local [[district attorney]], but he mostly ignored her.<ref name= aaol /> So she took her story to ''[[The Hartford Courant]]''. On May 9, 1916, the first of several articles on the "Murder Factory" was published.<ref name= factory>{{cite news| url= | title= Police Believe Archer Home for Aged a Murder Factory | work= The Hartford Courant| date= May 9, 1916| access-date= }}</ref> A few months later, the police started to seriously investigate the case. The investigation took almost a year to complete.
The bodies of Gilligan, Andrews, and three other boarders were exhumed. All five had died of poisoning, either [[arsenic]] or [[strychnine]]. Local merchants were able to testify that Amy had been purchasing large quantities of arsenic, supposedly to "kill rats". A look into Gilligan's will established that it was actually a forgery written by Amy.<ref name= aaol />
According to [[M. William Phelps]], author of ''The Devil's Rooming House'', investigation appeared to show that Amy was buying the arsenic to kill large numbers of rats. However, it appears that she did not buy all of the arsenic which killed her patients. The doctor and some of the patients had signed off to purchase it. The investigation pursued Dr. King because more evidence was piling up against him, but suspicions were focused back on Amy when someone suggested to clearly check all records of arsenic purchases.
When evidence was found of Amy sending her patients to the drugstore to buy quantities of arsenic, the police were able to arrest and convict her.<ref>{{cite book| last= Phelps| first= M. William |year= 2010| title= The Devil's Rooming House| location= Guilford, Connecticut| publisher= Lyons Press| pages= 166–169}}</ref>
== Trials == Archer-Gilligan was arrested and tried for murder, originally on five counts. Ultimately her lawyer managed to have the charges reduced to a single count, the murder of Franklin R. Andrews. On June 18, 1917, a jury found her guilty, and she was sentenced to death.
Archer-Gilligan appealed and was granted a new trial in 1919. At this trial, she pleaded [[insanity defense|insanity]]. Mary Archer testified that her mother was addicted to [[morphine]]. Archer-Gilligan was again found guilty of murder and was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]].<ref name= aaol />
== Death == In 1924, Archer-Gilligan was declared to be temporarily insane and was transferred to the [[Connecticut Valley Hospital|Connecticut Hospital for the Insane]] in Middletown, where she remained until her death on April 23, 1962.<ref name= courant /><ref name= aaol />
== See also == * [[Crime in Connecticut]] * [[List of serial killers in the United States]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book| last= Phelps| first= M. William| title= The Devil's Rooming House: The True Story of America's Deadliest Female Serial Killer| publisher= Rowman & Littlefield| date= June 1, 2011 |isbn= 9780762762507}}
== External links == * {{cite web | first= Charles| last= Montaldo| url= http://crime.about.com/od/murder/p/gilligan.htm |title= Amy Archer-Gilligan and Her Murder Factory| website= About.com}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Archer-Gilligan, Amy}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1962 deaths]] [[Category:1907 murders in the United States]] [[Category:20th-century American criminals]] [[Category:American female serial killers]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:American prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment]] [[Category:American serial killers]] [[Category:Criminals from Connecticut]] [[Category:Deaths in mental institutions]] [[Category:Health care professionals convicted of murdering patients]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in Connecticut detention]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Connecticut]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by Connecticut]] [[Category:Mariticides]] [[Category:Murderers for life insurance money]] [[Category:People from Newington, Connecticut]] [[Category:Poisoners]]
