{{Orphan|date=October 2017}}
Various organizations of practicing [[chiropractor]]s have outlined formal codes of '''professional ethics'''. Actual practice has revealed a wide range of behaviors which may or may not conform to these standards.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}}
== Official positions ==
The [[American Chiropractic Association]] (ACA) has a "Code of Ethics"<ref name="ACA">{{Cite web|author=Staff|title=Code of Ethics|publisher=[[American Chiropractic Association]]|url=http://www.acatoday.org/content_css.cfm?CID=719}}</ref> "based upon the acknowledgement that the social contract dictates the profession’s responsibilities to the patient, the public, and the profession; and upholds the fundamental principle that the paramount purpose of the chiropractic doctor's professional services shall be to benefit the patient." The smaller [[International Chiropractor's Association]] (ICA) also has a detailed set of professional canons.<ref name="ICA">{{Cite web|author=Staff|title=ICA code of Ethics|publisher=[[International Chiropractor's Association]]|url=http://www.chiropractic.org/ica/ethics.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140405120410/http://www.chiropractic.org/ica/ethics.htm|archivedate=2014-04-05|df=}}</ref>
== Reports of actual practice ==
Various situations have occurred in which the ethics of chiropractors and chiropractic organizations have been called into question.
A 2008 commentary proposed that the chiropractic profession actively regulate itself to combat abuse, fraud, and [[quackery]], which are more prevalent in chiropractic than in other health care professions, violating the [[social contract]] between patients and physicians.<ref name=Murphy-pod/>
Gleberzon ''et al.'' identify "deliberate fraud" as a notably harmful element of the chiropractic profession, finding that dubious practice techniques can translate into "outlandish billing and utilization rates".<ref name="Gleberzon2005"/> Those at the "fringe of ethical behavior" present the profession with a challenge, they believe, and must be weeded out.<ref name="Gleberzon2005">{{cite journal |first1=Brian J. |last1=Gleberzon |first2=Robert |last2=Cooperstein |first3=Stephen M. |last3=Perle |journal=Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association |title=Can chiropractic survive its chimerical nature? |pmid=17549192 |pmc=1840015 |year=2005 |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=69–73}}</ref>
A study of California disciplinary statistics during 1997–2000 reported 4.5 disciplinary actions per 1000 chiropractors per year, compared to 2.27 for medical doctors, and the incident rate for fraud was nine times greater among chiropractors (1.99 per 1000 chiropractors per year) than among medical doctors (0.20).<ref name=Foreman>{{cite journal |vauthors=Foreman SM, Stahl MJ |title=Chiropractors disciplined by a state chiropractic board and a comparison with disciplined medical physicians |journal=J Manipulative Physiol Ther |volume=27 |issue=7 |pages=472–7 |date=September 2004 |pmid=15389179 |doi=10.1016/j.jmpt.2004.06.006}}</ref> According to a 2006 Gallup poll of U.S. adults, when asked how they would "rate the honesty and ethical standards of people in these different fields", chiropractic compared unfavorably with mainstream medicine. When chiropractic was rated, it "rated dead last amongst healthcare professions". While 84% of respondents considered nurses' ethics "very high" or "high," only 36% felt that way about chiropractors. Other healthcare professions ranged from 38% for psychiatrists, to 62% for dentists, 69% for medical doctors, 71% for veterinarians, and 73% for druggists or pharmacists.<ref name=Murphy-pod>{{cite journal|pmid=18759966|doi=10.1186/1746-1340-16-10|url=http://chiroandosteo.com/content/pdf/1746-1340-16-10.pdf|date=Aug 2008 |last1=Murphy |first1=DR |last2=Schneider |last3=Seaman |last4=Perle|last5=Nelson|title=How can chiropractic become a respected mainstream profession? The example of podiatry|volume=16|page=10|journal=Chiropractic & osteopathy|first2=MJ|first3=DR|first4=SM|first5=CF|pmc=2538524}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |journal=Dynamic Chiropractic |volume=25 |issue=3 |date=29 January 2007 |title=Gallup Poll: Americans have low opinion of chiropractors' honesty and ethics |url=http://dynamicchiropractic.com/mpacms/dc/article.php?id=52038}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=USA TODAY/Gallup poll |url=http://usatoday.com/news/polls/tables/live/2006-12-11-ethics.htm |work=[[USA Today]] |date=11 December 2006}}</ref><ref name=Gallup_chart>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/1654/honesty-ethics-professions.aspx|title=Honesty/Ethics in Professions|first=Gallup,|last=Inc.|publisher=}}</ref> Similar results were found in the 2003 Gallup Poll.<ref name=Gallup_2003>"[http://www.gallup.com/poll/9823/public-rates-nursing-most-honest-ethical-profession.aspx Public Rates Nursing as Most Honest and Ethical Profession]." [[Gallup Poll]], 2003</ref>
In 2001, the largest chiropractic associations in the U.S. and Canada were reported to have distributed patient brochures which contained unsubstantiated claims.<ref name=Unsubstantiated>{{cite journal |vauthors=Grod JP, Sikorski D, Keating JC |title=Unsubstantiated claims in patient brochures from the largest state, provincial, and national chiropractic associations and research agencies |journal=J Manipulative Physiol Ther |volume=24 |issue=8 |pages=514–9 |date=October 2001 |pmid=11677551 |doi=10.1067/mmt.2001.118205}}</ref> Chiropractors, especially in America, have a reputation for unnecessarily treating patients. In many circumstances the focus seems to be put on economics instead of health care.<ref name=Trick-or-Treatment>{{cite book|pages=145–90|chapter=The truth about chiropractic therapy|title=[[Trick or Treatment: The Undeniable Facts about Alternative Medicine]]|vauthors=Singh S, Ernst E |year=2008|publisher=W.W. Norton|isbn=978-0-393-06661-6 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Samsonov|first1=Mike|title=Chiropractic Therapy As a Method of Treatment|url=http://www.betterhealthbeauty.com/2017/03/04/chiropractic-therapy-as-a-method-of-treatment/}}</ref> Sustained chiropractic care is promoted as a preventative tool, but unnecessary manipulation could possibly present a risk to patients.<ref name=Ernst-eval/> Some chiropractors are concerned by the routine unjustified claims chiropractors have made.<ref name=Ernst-eval>{{cite journal|journal= [[J Pain Symptom Manage]]|year=2008|volume=35|issue=5|pages=544–62|title= Chiropractic: a critical evaluation|author= Ernst E|doi=10.1016/j.jpainsymman.2007.07.004|pmid=18280103 }}</ref> A 2010 analysis of chiropractic websites found the majority of chiropractors and their associations made claims of effectiveness not supported by scientific evidence, while 28% of chiropractic websites advocate lower back pain care, which has some sound evidence.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=20389316|year=2010|last1=Ernst|first1=E|last2=Gilbey|first2=A|title=Chiropractic claims in the English-speaking world|volume=123|issue=1312|pages=36–44 |journal=The New Zealand medical journal}}</ref>
Although in the vast majority of US States [[chiropractors]] are considered [[physicians]] pursuant to statute{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} (exceptions are ''inter alia'', [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[California]]). The Joint Commission recognizes chiropractors as physicians as well.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Joint Commission Perspectives|url=http://www.acatoday.org/content_css.cfm?CID=4038|title=The Joint Commission Now Recognizes Chiropractors as Physicians}}</ref> In some jurisdictions, like New Zealand, chiropractors appeared to have used the title 'doctor' in a New Zealand yellow pages telephone directory in a way that implied they are registered medical practitioners, when no evidence was presented it was true.<ref name=Gilbey>{{cite journal |author=Gilbey A |title=Use of inappropriate titles by New Zealand practitioners of acupuncture, chiropractic, and osteopathy |journal=N. Z. Med. J. |volume=121 |issue=1278 |pages=15–20 |date=July 2008 |pmid=18670471}}</ref> In New Zealand, chiropractors are allowed to use the title 'doctor' when it is qualified to show that the title refers to their chiropractic role. A representative from the NZ Chiropractic Board states that entries in the yellow pages under the heading of 'Chiropractors' fulfills this obligation when suitably qualified.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Bale K |title=Chiropractic Board New Zealand response to "Dr Who?" editorial |journal=N. Z. Med. J. |volume=121 |issue=1280 |pages=78–9 |date=August 2008 |pmid=18791634}}</ref> If a chiropractor is not a registered medical practitioner, then the misuse of the title 'doctor' while working in healthcare will not comply with the [[Health Practitioners Competence Assurance Act 2003]].<ref name=Gilbey/>
UK chiropractic organizations and their members make numerous claims which are not supported by scientific evidence. Many chiropractors adhere to ideas which are against science and most seemingly violate important principles of ethical behaviour on a regular basis. The advice chiropractors gave to their patients is often misleading and dangerous.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ernst E |title=UK chiropractic: regulated but unruly |journal=J Health Serv Res Policy |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=186–7 |date=July 2009 |pmid=19541879 |doi=10.1258/jhsrp.2009.008183}}</ref> In 2009, a [[backlash (sociology)|backlash]] to the [[Simon Singh#Chiropractic lawsuit|libel suit filed by the British Chiropractic Association (BCA) against Simon Singh]], has inspired the filing of formal complaints of false advertising against more than 500 individual chiropractors within one 24-hour period,<ref name=withdraw>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.nature.com/news/thegreatbeyond/2009/06/chiropractic_group_advises_mem_1.html |title=The Great Beyond: Chiropractic group advises members to 'withdraw from the battleground' |publisher=Nature.com |author=Lucas Laursen |accessdate=20 June 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.nature.com/news/thegreatbeyond/2009/06/chiropractic_complainers_ident.html |title=The Great Beyond: Complaints converge on chiropractors |publisher=Nature.com |author=Lucas Laursen |accessdate=20 June 2009}}</ref> prompting the McTimoney Chiropractic Association to write to its members advising them to remove leaflets that make claims about whiplash and colic from their practice, to be wary of new patients and telephone inquiries, and telling their members: "If you have a website, take it down NOW." and "Finally, we strongly suggest you do NOT discuss this with others, especially patients."<ref name=withdraw/> An editorial in ''Nature'' has suggested that the BCA may be trying to suppress debate and that this use of British libel law is a burden on the right to freedom of expression, which is protected by the [[European Convention on Human Rights]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Unjust burdens of proof |journal=Nature|volume=459 |issue=7248 |page=751 |date=June 2009 |pmid=19516290|doi=10.1038/459751a}}</ref> The libel case ended with the BCA withdrawing its suit in 2010.<ref name="news">{{cite news|title=Case dropped against Simon Singh|author=Pallab Ghosh|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8621880.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=2010-04-15}}</ref><ref name="Mark Henderson">{{cite news|publisher=Times Online|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/article7098157.ece|title=Science writer Simon Singh wins bitter libel battle|author=Mark Henderson|location=London|date=2010-04-16}}</ref>
==Tenets==
* [http://www.acatoday.org/level2_css.cfm?T1ID=15&T2ID=160 ACA's Page on Ethical Practice] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140405120410/http://www.chiropractic.org/ica/ethics.htm ICA Ethics].
==See also==
* [[Chiropractic]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.chiroethics.com/ Institute for Chiropractic Ethics] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140405120410/http://www.chiropractic.org/ica/ethics.htm ICA Canons of Ethics]

revision.comment: Copying from [[Category:17th-century English writers]] to [[Category:17th-century male writers]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Capt. Christopher Levett | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Christopher Levett | birth_date = 5 April 1586 | birth_place=[[York]], England | death_date = {{death year and age|1630|1586}} | death_place = aboard the ''Porcupine'', Atlantic ocean | death_cause = | resting_place = buried at sea | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = English | other_names = | known_for = explorer of [[New England]]; granted 6,000 acres to settle Colony of York (now [[Portland, Maine]]), 15 May 1623 | education = | employer = | occupation = English naval captain, explorer, author | title = Captain; His Majesty's Woodward of Somersetshire; Principal, [[Plymouth Council for New England]] | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = Mercy Levett (''née'' More); Frances Levett (''née'' Lottisham) | partner = | children = Sarah Levett Hitch; Mary Levett; Rev. Jeremiah Levett; Timothy Levett; Elizabeth Levett | parents = [[Percival Levett]], Elizabeth (''née'' Rotherforth) Levett | relatives = | signature = Christopher Levett Signature.svg | website = | footnotes = }} [[File:Christopher Levett.jpg|thumb|right|175px|[[Book frontispiece|Frontispiece]], ''A Voyage into New-England, Begun in 1623, and Ended in 1624, Performed by Christopher Levett, his Majesties Woodward of Somersetshire, and one of the Councell of New-England'']] '''Capt. Christopher Levett''' (15 April 1586 – 1630) was an English writer, explorer and naval captain, born at [[York]], England.<ref>The Levett family from which Christopher Levett derived came from Bolton Percy, Yorkshire. But this York family shared a coat-of-arms with the Levetts of Normanton and High Melton, Yorkshire, sort of an early DNA assay, indicating that the two families had common roots. Christopher Levett's coat-of-arms appeared in an early survey of Sherborne, Dorset, where was residing. [https://books.google.com/books?id=uL7g4ps1Uj8C&pg=RA2-PA766&lpg=RA2-PA766&dq=levet+sherborne+dorset&source=web&ots=aTfXN3H2vz&sig=5Hjhd-fF0UfWeOQyOyLJ6nT7P4k&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result]</ref> He explored the coast of [[New England]] and secured a grant from the [[Charles I of England|King]] to settle present-day [[Portland, Maine]], the first European to do so. Levett left behind a group of settlers at his Maine plantation in [[Casco Bay]], but they were never heard from again. Their fate is unknown. As a member of the [[Plymouth Council for New England]], Levett was named the Governor of Plymouth<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hs_28mtwTroC&pg=PA67&lpg=PA67&dq=%22christopher+levet%22&source=bl&ots=JxMXzlkB2q&sig=g-Yjg9Xr6ktc26XBJL25hBlg2rc&hl=en&ei=fXS8SrGrFoKysgO_8azcBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levet%22&f=false New-England's Memorial, Nathaniel Morton, William Bradford, Thomas Prince, Edward Winslow, Congregational Board of Publication, Boston, 1855]</ref> in 1623 and a close adviser to Capt. [[Robert Gorges]] in his attempt to found an early English colony at [[Weymouth, Massachusetts]], which also failed.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=uVIWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA159&dq=%22christopher+levite%22&ei=rQu8SpCNAarakQSfqumTDw#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levite%22&f=false Bradford's History of Plymouth Plantation, 1606–1646, Charles Scribner's Sons, New York, 1920]</ref><ref>The length of Levett's service as Governor of Plymouth is unknown, but he returned to England the year following his appointment (1624), and during his time in New England seems to have been constantly on the move. Also unclear are what Levett's duties were as Governor of Plymouth, in which capacity he is referred to as the 'chief judicial officer,' with 'Esquire' appended to his name.[https://books.google.com/books?id=mqBdpS-IkbMC&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=%22christopher+levet%22&source=bl&ots=nqQ2MpkI2J&sig=at5snaErmQQDiapeE7cwp1VPeY4&hl=en&ei=cXa8SrfkAY3QtAP46IG7BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levet%22&f=false][https://books.google.com/books?id=QKETAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA206&lpg=RA1-PA206&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+governor+general+new+england&source=bl&ots=heCmIO6tJw&sig=QVLXQAIB1bHLZUDVzDKsMAmxQO8&hl=en&ei=0Wu8So4qguqxA8aX4NwF&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levett%22%20governor%20general%20new%20england&f=false][https://books.google.com/books?id=nH7-nOInwJgC&pg=PA79&dq=%22christopher+levite%22&ei=IBC8SouiPJ2slQSBmdnsDg#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levite%22&f=false][https://books.google.com/books?id=mGcOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA328&dq=levett&lr=&ei=gFG7SvjpOJnUkgSHvoGNDA#v=onepage&q=levett&f=false][https://books.google.com/books?id=JD8OAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA238&lpg=PA238&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+governor+general+new+england&source=bl&ots=FkxJrhAKrd&sig=LCGROgZ_U3-5QpQjGVe4BZMTmsU&hl=en&ei=KYm8SqisGYfUtgOxqvS6BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levett%22%20governor%20general%20new%20england&f=false][https://books.google.com/books?id=BA_jC9qnxzMC&pg=PA110&dq=%22christopher+levitt%22&lr=&ei=AYu8SuqFCZv8lATL0_X0Dg#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levitt%22&f=false] Governor [[William Bradford (Plymouth governor)|William Bradford]] of the [[Plymouth Colony]] refers to the explorer as "Christoper Levite." Nathaniel Morton, Bradford's nephew and the colony's secretary, calls him "Christopher Levet." Record-keeping in the early days of the colony was sometimes sporadic.</ref> Levett was also named an early governor of Virginia in 1628, according to Parliamentary records at [[Whitehall]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BtEJAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+virginia&source=bl&ots=Bp2TFhjwVN&sig=yND95fnJ1bluN-2mvdhwInFMHfA&hl=en&ei=1KS8SoyIGo2csgPUqYS7BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levett%22%20virginia&f=false Calendar of State Papers, Great Britain Public Record Office, Vol. 6, Colonial Series, William Noel Sainsbury, John William Fortescue, Cecil Headlam (eds.), Her Majesty's Stationery Office, London, 1860]</ref>
==Life== [[Levett]] was the son of Elizabeth and [[Percival Levett]], a York merchant and innkeeper, and was admitted a freeman of York as a merchant himself.<ref>[https://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=48281 Xpoferus Levett, marcer, fil. Percivalli Levett, gent., Admissions to the freedom of York, Temp. James I (1603–1625), British History Online]</ref> Levett was also admitted to the [[Merchant Adventurers' Hall|Company of Merchant Adventurers in the City of York]], along with his brother Percival.<ref>{{ cite book |title=The Company of Merchant Adventurers in the City of York: Register of Admissions 1581–1835 |last=Smith|first=David M.|publisher=[[University of York]]|year=1996|place=York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XTJVUxZuwxMC&pg=PA36&dq=levett+knaresborough&hl=en&ei=XDHkTd-gAaLiiAL28tGXBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=levett%20knaresborough&f=false }}</ref> There is evidence that the English attempts to colonise North America caught Levett's interest even while a York merchant. Rev. [[Alexander Whitaker]], an early Anglican minister and English immigrant to the [[Virginia Colony]] made note in his will of 1610 that he owed a debt of some £5 to "Christopher Levite, a linen draper of the city of York."
Perhaps Levett's contact with Whitaker and other Englishmen stoked his zeal to become an explorer. Levett apparently grew restless, and instead turned his sights towards a career as an explorer. He served as His Majesty's Woodward of [[Somerset]]shire to King [[James I of England|James I]], and wrote a tract on [[logging|timber harvesting]] that became the standard for selection of trees for the [[Royal Navy]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=yETLcuNxk18C&pg=PA176&lpg=PA176&dq=levett+dorsetshire&source=web&ots=xAJYagEOQB&sig=TDVfgBYiBqsa7N8n_u2ZAgXmp9o&hl=en Collections of the Maine Historical Society, Second Series, Vol. IV, Published by the Society, Portland, 1893]</ref>
Later, operating from his adopted home in [[Sherborne]], Dorset, in the shadow of [[Sir Walter Raleigh]] and other adventurers, Levett became interested in the colonisation of [[New England]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=bYohAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA8&lpg=RA2-PA8&dq=levett+sherburne+dorset&source=web&ots=yEhe5M1LoV&sig=ysjRLQ1PPfbY9RfJyHx2UL9cTzc&hl=en#PRA2-PA9,M1 Historical Addresses, James Baxter Phinney, 1831–1921, Portland, Maine]</ref> Levett became associated with Sir [[Ferdinando Gorges]] and was appointed to the [[Plymouth Council for New England|Council for New England]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nec7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA667&lpg=PA667&dq=%22his+majesty's+woodward%22&source=web&ots=xux5Nc9Htk&sig=ZwNXPOawHYBH7s19tdEauJ6M1nM&hl=en Provincial and State Papers, New Hampshire Colony Probate Court, 1895]</ref> He was granted {{convert|6000|acre|km2}} of land by King [[James I of England]] for a settlement in present-day [[Maine]], which Levett proposed to call "York" after his birth city.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=U2nDKCqyoYAC&pg=PA605&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+sherborne&lr=&ei=Lt0bSZbOEI_gswObs4zbCA Forerunners and Competitors of the Pilgrims and Puritans Or, Narratives of Voyages Made by Persons Other Than the Pilgrims and Puritans of the Bay Colony to the Shores of New England During the First Quarter of the Seventeenth Century, 1601–1625, with Especial Reference to the Labors of Captain John Smith, Vol. 2, Charles Herbert Levermore, New England Society of Brooklyn, N.Y., Published by The Society, New York, 1912]</ref>
On 5 May 1623, records for the Council on New England say, "Christopher Levett to be a principal patentee; and to have a grant of {{convert|6000|acre|km2}} of land." The next month, on 26 June 1623, the records note "the King judges well of the undertaking in New England, and more particularly of a design of Christopher Levett, one of the Council for settling that plantation, to build a city and call it York."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=h4Wy3OQQDioC&pg=PA62&lpg=PA62&dq=%22capt+christopher+levett%22&source=web&ots=H5fcbNR846&sig=y4CNFkGXNl_MscU01XkvjsKlR4U&hl=en#PPA62,M1 History of Boothbay, Southport and Boothbay Harbor, Maine, 1623–1905, Francis Byron Greene, 1906]</ref> The King proclaimed that [[Anglican]] churches across England should take up collections to add Levett in his settlement attempts.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Zc2iPZ4jN2AC&pg=PA11&dq=levett&lr=&ei=sTa7SrulL5CqkATa0cz4Dw#v=onepage&q=levett&f=false Coming Over: Migration and Communication Between England and New England in the Seventeenth Century, David Cressy, Cambridge University Press, 1987]</ref>
Levett was helped with his settlement ambitions, according to some historians, thanks to a deepening friendship with [[George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham]], the favoured courtier who acted as advocate for the young Yorkshireman. Levett's alliance to a powerful patron probably accounted for Levett's move to Sherborne and his appointment in the Royal forest in Somersetshire, putting him closer to Gorges and other early adventurers.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=yETLcuNxk18C&pg=PA176&lpg=PA176&dq=levett+sherborne+dorset&source=web&ots=xALRibJONJ&sig=gX-fL_P0GQCW8f7WRBRRF3-WCdw&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=8&ct=result#PPA174,M1 Christopher Levett: The First Owner of the Soil of Portland, James Phinney Baxter, read before the Maine Historical Society, 26 February 1891, Collections of the Maine Historical Society, Brown Thurston Company, Portland, Me., 1893]</ref>
On 26 June 1623, [[Secretary of State (England)|Secretary of State]] [[Edward Conway, 1st Viscount Conway|Lord Conway]] wrote to [[Emanuel Scrope, 1st Earl of Sunderland|Lord Scrope]], President of the [[Council of the North]], urging him to assist Levett in his plan to settle a plantation in New England with a company of Yorkshiremen and found "a Citty and call it by the name of Yorke." Noted the historian Charles Herbert Levermore: "So the first New York that was planned for America was to be located in Portland harbor."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=U2nDKCqyoYAC&pg=PA605&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+sherborne&lr=&ei=Lt0bSZbOEI_gswObs4zbCA Forerunners and Competitors of the Pilgrims and Puritans: Or, Narratives of Voyages Made by Persons Other Than the Pilgrims and Puritans of the Bay Colony to the Shores of New England During the First Quarter of the Seventeenth Century, 1601–1625, with Especial Reference to the Labors of Captain John Smith, Vol. 2, Charles Herbert Levermore, New England Society of Brooklyn, N.Y., 1912]</ref>
Oblivious to the high-flying spiritual message of early Puritan founders of the [[Massachusetts Bay Colony]], Sir Ferdinando Gorges, his partner John Mason and other merchant adventurers zeroed in on profit.<ref>Many historians point to the efforts of Gorges and Mason, as well as their fellow Council member Levett, as attempts to plant the [[Church of England]] on the northern border of the Puritan [[Massachusetts Bay Colony]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=AXNdcKf22YoC&pg=PA16&dq=%22virginia+colony%22+levett&ei=Y4kfSe-FAZHakASI6czADw]</ref> From what we know of Levett, he seems more nuanced: his dealings with Native Americans seem solicitous, especially given the era, and his first wife was the daughter of a prominent Puritan rector.
Nevertheless, either out of an explorer's zeal or a businessman's gimlet eye, Levett forged ahead. To further his plans, the Naval captain embarked from England on a trip to explore the coast of New England, paying particular attention to present-day Maine and [[New Hampshire]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=iucc3Hmio-UC&pg=PA49&lpg=PA49&dq=%22capt+christopher+levett%22&source=web&ots=DAr6fJqKfE&sig=KydRg_Cq9Pj4T1duwFsX9mB_J00&hl=en The Isles of Shoals, John Scribner Jenness, 1873]</ref>
When he returned to England, he wrote a book called "A Voyage into New England, Begun in 1623, and Ended in 1624, Performed by Christopher Levett, His Majesty's Woodward of Somersetshire, and One of the Council of New England."<ref>[http://www.newenglandancestors.org/research/database/great_migration/L.asp#CHRISTOPHER_LEVETT New England Ancestors, New England Historic Genealogical Society]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gwKwEbZhv3cC&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=UQCWNF5RD2&sig=-i0t2SROIrUOLkSDt6Hob1bx1X8&hl=en#PPA79,M1 Christopher Levett of York: The Pioneer Colonist in Casco Bay, James Phinney Baxter, 1893]</ref> It was Levett's hope to stir settlement in the New World, and he hoped as the principal patentee (and first settler) of present-day [[Portland, Maine]], to benefit financially from the arrangement. [[Image:All Saints Pavement 3.jpg|thumb|left|175px|[[All Saints' Church, Pavement, York]], baptism of Christopher Levett, 5 April 1586]] On the surface, Capt. Levett seemed ideally placed to push such settlement. "When ''[[A Description of New England]]'' was published in London in 1616," write Charles and Samuella Shain of Capt. John Smith's book, "it was only a question of time before another enterprising spirit would arrive who would realize Captain John Smith's plans for founding a permanent settlement on the Maine coast.... Better placed socially and therefore politically than John Smith, Levett was also richer."<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=LB6jYtB3vlIC&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+%22john+smith%22&source=web&ots=1VZ7182KhT&sig=ZvQoQWOMwpLJtZ-vNeqyU8OSmDw&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result The Maine Reader, Charles Shain, Samuella Shain, Houghton Mifflin, Boston, 1991]</ref>
Levett apparently had his eye on New England's thriving fisheries, which English merchants had exploited for years. The naval captain reported to Gorges that with the region's best fishing in the winter months, settling a permanent colony would enable the merchant adventurers to double their profits, by enabling the ships to fish yearround.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nfDUSwHvQiUC&pg=PA332&dq=%22virginia+colony%22+christopher+levett&lr=&ei=oI4fSa2gE4_QkwS23JXhDw#PPA265,M1 Fish on Fridays: Feasting, Fasting, and the Discovery of the New World, Brian M. Fagan, Basic Books, 2006, SBN 0465022847]</ref>
But despite his better connections, the tide of history was not in his favour. His salesmanship fell short. Public interest waned, as new settlements in Virginia and elsewhere took center stage. King Charles I's growing problems ate away at interest in colonisation.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=3sQMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70&dq=levett+royal&source=web&ots=ftGgKXqhOp&sig=1J1UKdYjMsNxSazkxuFTR7pLXH8&hl=en Collections of the Maine Historical Society, Published by the Society, Portland, 1904]</ref> The King's appeal for money in Yorkshire parishes to support the Levett scheme never yielded much. The gathering storm of Roundhead rebellion put Levett's benefactors under strain.
In the meantime Levett was assigned to more pressing matters in England. On 5 October 1625, Capt. Levett was at the helm of [[Her Majesty's Ship|HMS]] ''Susan and Ellen'' as part of [[Edward Cecil, 1st Viscount Wimbledon|Lord Wimbledon]]'s fleet of 80 English and 16 Dutch vessels sailing against the Spanish fleet at [[Cadiz]]. The expedition, mounted by [[King Charles I of England|King Charles I]] who pressured his subjects to fund it, was an abject failure, and the fleet returned to England in disgrace.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gwKwEbZhv3cC&pg=PA32&dq=%22virginia+colony%22+christopher+levett&lr=&ei=1YofSf7xMZ-OkAS-mLD7Dw#PPA32,M1 Christopher Levett, of York, the Pioneer Colonist in Casco Bay, James Phinney Baxter, The Gorges Society, Portland, Me., 1893]</ref> Levett later complained bitterly of the experience, claiming that even as a [[Royal Navy]] captain, he'd been treated "no better than a meare slave" by those in charge.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=mGcOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA328&dq=levett&lr=&ei=gFG7SvjpOJnUkgSHvoGNDA#v=onepage&q=levett&f=false History of Plymouth Plantation, 1620n–1647, Vol. 1, William Bradford, Worthington Chauncey Ford (ed.), Massachusetts Historical Society, Published for the Society by Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, 1912]</ref>
Levett never returned to Maine, and the small group of men he left behind in a stone house were never heard from again. Levett's patented lands eventually passed to a group of [[Plymouth]] merchants as Levett's attention was diverted to more pressing Naval matters.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=L3LGHsjNVBUC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=sandys+levett&source=web&ots=8JBWrUj6Z6&sig=CFyBj0GHwqTQ7BEya2EHIvS1tyQ&hl=en Maine Pioneer Settlements, Herbert Milton Sylvester, W.B. Clarke Co., Boston, 1909]</ref> Eventually Levett returned to the [[Massachusetts Bay Colony]], where he met with Governor [[John Winthrop]] in 1630,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KIarrcIX7QAC&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=%22thomas+levet%22+%22new+hampshire%22&source=web&ots=fWej50Xr3p&sig=k9R7spxGrErPU0nhi27ct23GMAU&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result#PPA30,M1 The History of New England from 1630 to 1649, John Winthrop, 1853]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=LB6jYtB3vlIC&pg=PA10&lpg=PA10&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=bl&ots=1V11596QgY&sig=VjVGbiLnp_BQfsKZhZ2HdhS6Ys4&hl=en&ei=EaC1StvfAofSsgOA2_XRDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4#v=onepage&q=%22a%20voyage%20into%20new%20england%22%20levett&f=false The Maine Reader: The Down East Experience from 1614 to the Present, Samuella Shain, Charles E. Shain, Published by David R. Godine, Jaffrey, New Hampshire, 1997]</ref> and he died aboard the return voyage home.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=mGcOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA328&lpg=PA328&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=NE31knZ7dL&sig=2O_R5pQJxL5FMWCA7j9M8jPuD34&hl=en History of Plymouth Plantation, William Bradford, Massachusetts Historical Society, 1912]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=4DfmZIJyM2UC&pg=PA10&lpg=PA10&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=uYQKMjvqVP&sig=xjnE2sXfmPppDgQ7y5DC2ZtFpE4&hl=en Portland in the Past, William Goold, 1886]</ref> The body of the early adventurer was buried at sea, and his wife was forced to appear at a Bristol court the following year to recover his effects.<ref>Following Capt. Levett's death, his wife Frances (Lottisham) Levett appealed to her good friend, the mother-in-law of [[John Winthrop the Younger]], for help in recovering her late husband's effects. Winthrop's father-in-law Henry Payner then wrote to Winthrop in Massachusetts, "sollicting him to call for [[John Endicott|Captayne Endicott]] and [[Roger Conant (Salem)|Mr. Conant]] to examine them aboute it, and to doe for her what he can to helpe her to right."[https://books.google.com/books?id=Unc5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA118&dq=christopher+levet&lr=&ei=Yse1SqrnOYi0kATi1XQ#v=onepage&q=christopher%20levet&f=false]. Winthrop's father-in-law's letter, combined with the fact that Capt. Levett was carrying letters with him to England written by the colonists and critical of the English church, may indicate that Levett himself was experiencing a change of heart towards the ongoing conflict between the King and the Puritan cause.</ref> [[File:FortLevett.jpg|thumb|225px|[[Fort Levett]] and Ram Island Ledge, [[Cushing Island, Maine]], 1909]] [[Fort Levett]] on [[Cushing Island, Maine]]<ref>There is some question whether Levett's settlement was located on House Island or on nearby Cushing Island in Casco Bay. Historian James Phinney Baxter seems to suggest that Levett may have left his men behind on House.[https://books.google.com/books?id=gwKwEbZhv3cC&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+%22house+island%22&source=web&ots=UQEUNx1VCW&sig=NR_lNkz_2tbl7r6I8jppeDvGsIE&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result]</ref> in Portland Harbor is named for this early explorer. Present-day [[York County, Maine]], derives its name from Capt. Levett's early appellation for his Maine settlement.
Even in death, Capt. Levett could not avoid the controversies roiling the age. Letters he carried aboard the vessel'' Porcupine'', addressed by John Winthrop and other leaders of the Massachusetts Bay Colony to sympathetic friends in England, fell into the hands of Puritan foes in England, apparently after Levett's possessions were searched after his death.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=AxLVAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA118&lpg=PA118&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levet&source=bl&ots=uoSqN6sZkp&sig=H8ciJMsFM53fRgANvfxQYFPvCaU&hl=en&ei=lVK0Som8DIH8tAPl1YTSDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2#v=onepage&q=%22a%20voyage%20into%20new%20england%22%20levet&f=false The Winthrop Papers, Adam Winthrop, John Winthrop, Wait Still Winthrop, Collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society, Vol. 1, Fifth Series, Published by the Society, Boston, Mass., 1871]</ref> The letters stirred up some measure of controversy in England for the unfavorable stance the writers took toward the English church.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ihFsfyXwYXoC&pg=PA605&lpg=PA605&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+%22robert+more%22&source=bl&ots=4iHEWbiB-Z&sig=2dOuj6jqVzJAg2UDfZmZIvXZc1c&hl=en&ei=UmGzSuLeF5PWtgPyqaWeDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8#v=onepage&q=%22christopher%20levett%22%20%22robert%20more%22&f=false Forerunners and Competitors of the Pilgrims and Puritans, Vol. 2, Charles Herbert Levermore, Reprinted by BiblioBazaar, LLC, 2008]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gwKwEbZhv3cC&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74&dq=%22john+endicott%22+christopher+levett&source=bl&ots=UQHUHC8YAY&sig=qsu2xNXfG7V-wHIqC3d67AcatZU&hl=en&ei=v1mzSrPiAoO0sgOBpvXRDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=%22john%20endicott%22%20christopher%20levett&f=false Christopher Levett of York: The Pioneer Colonist in Casco Bay, James Phinney Baxter, Printed for the Gorges Society, Portland, Me., 1893]</ref>
Capt. Levett had six children, four by his first wife Mercy More, who was the daughter of Rev. Robert More, a [[Puritan]] rector in [[Guiseley]], Yorkshire. He married a second time to Frances Lottisham,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ojsRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA99&lpg=PA99&dq=%22oliver+lottisham%22&source=bl&ots=Ja2QDAnV6p&sig=qwVlieygJQcfnNGTNngCpJz56xM&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=2&ct=result#PPA99,M1 Abstracts of Somersetshire Wills, Etc, Frederick Arthur Crisp, Frederick Brown, Privately Printed for Frederick Arthur Crisp, 1888]</ref> daughter of Oliver Lottisham<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=paXRXTR6SXAC&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70&dq=%22oiver+lottisham%22&source=bl&ots=Z0zET39jen&sig=H1XQc36zHGDCOf_EmZt8Y-ayd14&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result A Visitation of the County of Somerset in the Year 1623, Frederic Thomas Colby, The Harleian Society, Mitchell and Hughes, London, 1876]</ref> of Somersetshire, and by her he had another two children.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hkjQ90cX71oC&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+jeremiah&source=web&ots=Mmkwvgqs6V&sig=ZEELxAvvd2ZPbvZBW7Bb7oUKuts&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result The New England Historical and Genealogical Register, Henry Fitz-Gilbert Waters, The New England Historic Genealogical Society, Published by the Society, Boston, 1913]</ref> A son, Jeremiah (Jeremy), graduated from [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], and became the rector of [[Leyton]], Essex.<ref>{{acad|id=LVT631J|name=Levett, Jeremy}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=dmQvAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA94&dq=%22christ+church%22+levet&lr=&ei=ErkbSZn0DIPWtgPMpuzrBQ A History of the Parish of Leyton, Essex, John Kennedy, Phelp Brothers, Leyton, 1894]</ref><ref>An examination of Leyton, Essex, records reveals that Jeremiah Levett also owned property at "Temple in the Forest of [[Knaresborough]]", [[North Yorkshire]]. His father being a Yorkshireman, it probably isn't surprising that Jeremiah Levett owned property in the county, although his exact ties to Knaresborough are unclear.[https://books.google.com/books?id=dmQvAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA94&dq=%22christ+church%22+levet&lr=&ei=ErkbSZn0DIPWtgPMpuzrBQ#PPA93,M1] A John Levett became rector of Knaresborough in 1668 and served for 25 years.[https://books.google.com/books?id=8wIWAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA293&dq=knaresborough+levet&lr=&ei=HMsbSfO_Hof0sQOp0pWAAw]</ref> His daughter Sarah married the Right Rev. Robert Hitch, Rector of [[Normanton, West Yorkshire]] and later [[Dean of York]].<ref>{{acad|id=HTC611R|name=Hitch, Robert}}</ref> [[File:James Phinney Baxter Portland.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[James Phinney Baxter]], mayor, [[Portland, Maine]], and Maine historian]]

Shain, Samuella Shain, 1997]
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=Nww9VNmgqaQC&pg=PA701&lpg=PA701&dq=%22capt+christopher+levett%22&source=web&ots=YHeX82020Q&sig=Ssb6A4lk5DYONl6LiSyxSjhpQ3s&hl=en Grant to Levett, A Bibliography of the State of Maine from the Earliest Period to 1891, Joseph Williamson, Maine Historical Society, 1891] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=fDcZzZmwcZgC&pg=PA194&lpg=PA194&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=Dtqivrr1Vh&sig=u0wROEqohJ5_yinSoeH72aOGDWA&hl=en The Beginnings of Colonial Maine: 1602–1658, Henry Sweetser Burrage, 1914] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=gwKwEbZhv3cC&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=UQCWOw5TC2&sig=07uDfl4NyQDn7QA0Cm9btGZBnYU&hl=en A Voyage into New England, Christopher Levett, reprinted by James Phinney Baxter, 1893] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=d5fpE_cEtLAC&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=e1sWl6syAD&sig=u821LCpn3uXCS0YYfADLjTFZKM0&hl=en History of the Town of Rye, New Hampshire: From Its Discovery and Settlement, Langdon Brown Parsons, 1905] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=Nss1AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=%22a+voyage+into+new+england%22+levett&source=web&ots=ZTEBDxEi4_&sig=UfZ2ehU3ejfrI9GSdbUjHgoeDTY&hl=en A Documentary History of Chelsea: Including the Boston Precincts, Mellen Chamberlain, Massachusetts Historical Society, 1908] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080517100531/http://www.newenglandancestors.org/research/database/genealogies/levett/default.asp Christopher Levett of York, the Pioneer Colonist of Casco Bay, NewEnglandAncestors.org, New England Historic and Genealogical Society] *[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1916/07/23/104237584.pdf Sale of Capt. Christopher Levett "Voyage into New England," Sotheby's, The New York Times, 23 July 1916] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=bYohAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA21-IA2&lpg=RA1-PA21-IA2&dq=%22christopher+levett%22+sherborne&source=web&ots=yEhadH5NkV&sig=Micgt3JYzPEi7KK66S1Q1KtuNoc&hl=en Christopher Levett, The First Owner of the Soil of Portland, James Phinney Baxter, Maine Historical Society, 1877] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=paXRXTR6SXAC&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70&dq=oliver+lottisham+somersetshire&source=web&ots=Z0xDX6cfdm&sig=khpE_Ay55K_dpFnKMYoNyB1vNxI&hl=en Christopher Levyt, York, Frances Lottisham, Farrington, Somerset, Pedigree, The Visitation of the County of Somerset in the Year 1623, Samson Lennard, 1876] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZhoFAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=%22great+britain+public+record+office%22+levett&source=web&ots=wON5Rf4aW4&sig=DajoYucq73PDi5idg48u3RD5QkA&hl=en The King Judges Well, Calendar of State Papers, Colonial Series, Great Britain Public Record Office, William Noel Sainsbury, 1860] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=DfAOAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA229&lpg=RA1-PA229&dq=levett+ireland&source=web&ots=yV1iBsfATx&sig=AnOavmPXANiCzjJgx1Lnh2hF2Nk&hl=en#PRA1-PA228,M1 Colonization in Maine, 1623, Original Documents (State Paper Office, London), The Historical Magazine and Notes Concerning the Antiquities, History and Biography of America, John Gilmary Shea, New York, London, 1860]
